column4: I have used the kaffeine plugin before to play realplayer videos.
I'm not sure if you already need realplayer installed in order for kaffeine to play the videos, though.
is kaffeine a firefox plugin?
kaffeine is a media player.  You need to install kaffeine-mozilla separately to play embedded videos.
Coll Ill try that
I personally have no problem with realplayer.  The only flaw I see in realplayer is that it does not maximinze embedded videos on linux.

the problem I have with it is on the windows side it installs so much crap and trys to associate itself with all your media files and dont even talk about the mesage centre. As I am now switching to open source I want to try and stick will all open source stuff.
realplayer on linux is different.  It doesn't have all the B.S. it has on windows.
I use realplayer when it is opened externally on linux.  It works great in that scenario.
you may need to uninstall the totem plugin for mozilla in order to play streaming windows media videos.
here is a good site to test realplayer and windows media videos:  http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/view/
here is an example of where realplayer opens externally.  This is where realplayer works well on linux:  http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=06/05/26/141024
thanks for the help I have only been using ubuntu for a couple of weeks but I am loving it.
you need the win32 codecs to play windows videos
I'm still fairly new to linux but I have gotten it to do just about everything windows does so far.

I think it is getting very close to being full replacement. I enjoy hacking around with the terminal but I think less technically minded may still find it a little tricky but its not far from prime time.
I don't consider myself too technically minded.  I'm not a programmer.  I just started playing with linux once and since then i've been hooked.

I recommend installing several video players.  Some videos don't play in some players.  I think it has to do with codec stuff.  I have kaffeine, xine, mplayer, and totem installed.  I use amarok and xmms for audio.
I also use VLC which I have found to be excellent
if you want ideas to make your desktop look a lot cooler, check out these sites:  http://www.gnome-look.org/   http://www.kde-look.org/
